<<<api>>>: PrintWriter.write
<<<code>>>: try {
    PrintWriter writer = new PrintWriter("C:/path/to/directory/twitterData_"+currDate+".txt", "UTF-8");
    writer.println("TweetId,UserScreenName,Tweet,TimeStamp");
    writer.close();
} catch (Exception e) {
    e.printStackTrace();
}
<<<explanation>>>: In order to specify a directory for the file to be created, you need to provide the full path to the directory in the file name parameter of the PrintWriter constructor. Make sure to replace "C:/path/to/directory" with the actual directory path where you want the file to be created. Additionally, make sure to close the PrintWriter after writing to the file.

} catch (Exception e) {

<<<api>>>: PrintWriter.write
<<<code>>>: try {
    String directoryPath = "C:/path/to/directory";
    File directory = new File(directoryPath);
    if (!directory.exists()) {
        directory.mkdirs();
    }
    
    String filePath = directoryPath + "/twitterData_" + currDate + ".txt";
    PrintWriter writer = new PrintWriter(filePath, "UTF-8");
    writer.println("TweetId,UserScreenName,Tweet,TimeStamp");
    writer.close();
} catch (Exception e) {
    e.printStackTrace();
}
<<<explanation>>>: To specify a directory for the file, you can create a File object with the directory path and use the mkdirs() method to create the directory if it doesn't exist. Then, you can concatenate the directory path with the file name to create the file path. Finally, you can create a PrintWriter object with the file path and "UTF-8" encoding, and use the println() method to write the content to the file.

<<<api>>>: PrintWriter.write
<<<code>>>: try {
    File directory = new File("path/to/directory");
    directory.mkdirs(); // create the directory if it doesn't exist
    PrintWriter writer = new PrintWriter(new File(directory, "twitterData_"+currDate+".txt"), "UTF-8");
    writer.println("TweetId,UserScreenName,Tweet,TimeStamp");
    writer.close();
} catch (Exception e) {
    e.printStackTrace();
}
<<<explanation>>>: In order to specify a directory for the file to be created, you can use the File class to create a File object with the desired directory path. You can then use the PrintWriter constructor that takes a File object as an argument to specify the directory and file name. The mkdirs() method is used to create the directory if it doesn't already exist. The "UTF-8" encoding is also specified for the PrintWriter. Finally, the writer is closed to ensure that all data is written to the file.
